Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a 2015 standalone prequel and expansion to the critically acclaimed and underrated game, Wolfenstein: The New Order (2014). A solid and terrific first-person shooter at its own right, The Old Blood doesn’t change much from The New Order in regards to gameplay mechanics. However, I personally enjoyed the gameplay mechanics even though it is, obviously, recycled from The New Order. The review applies to people who never played MachineGames’ vision of Wolfenstein or people who already had The New Order on the Steam Library. The question remains: Should I get The Old Blood and why?  The Old Blood takes place in Castle Wolfenstein (yes, literally) around 1946. The Nazis are winning the war over the Allies and you must stop them from declaring decisive victory. You play as William “B.J” Blazkowicz, an OSS agent who must infiltrate the Castle to gather intelligence on Deathshead’s Compound (where your arch nemesis resides) and assassinate him. Interestingly, the Old Blood takes place just before the prologue chapter in The New Order. There are interesting characters in The Old Blood, including notables such as Helga Von Schabbs and notable references from previous Wolfenstein titles. The story is pretty good and has great homage to Return to Castle Wolfenstein (2002) and the developers respectfully placed references that old school gamers would recognized.   The gameplay is simple: shoot and kill Nazis. That’s it. Nothing else. This may sound so typical for a first-person school and it is, but every Nazi you kill feels very satisfying. The weapons and character movement are great and highly outstanding. The walkthrough would last you around 4-6 hours, but there are some replay values on getting achievements or finding secrets. The best part in The Old Blood is revisiting Wolfenstein 3D by sleeping on a bed (which the beds are in secret areas). Finding the secrets will bring you great rewards and nostalgia. Alongside with the storyline to fulfill MachineGames’ lore on Wolfenstein, Old Blood offers “Challenge Mode” (or challenge maps) and it is really great. Kill the Nazis and accumulate points on reaching certain criteria for bronze, silver, or gold.   While The Old Blood has great merits, there are some negative attributes that has to be taken in consideration. First, the content doesn’t seem much but the storage requirements is insanely huge (all thanks to the iD Tech 5 engine), taking around 38 GB of your hard drive or SSD. This is roughly the same storage space as The New Order, but has fewer content. Individuals who have poor internet connection or low download speeds will have to exercise caution on installing and downloading the game (and wait for hours). The game engine is pretty and impressive, but the engine suffers frequent popup textures or objects were blurry and takes a few seconds to adjust itself to its proper graphical design. In my experience, this happens more often in The Old Blood than The New Order.   The Old Blood (standalone expansion/DLC) is outstanding and I really enjoy it. Even though there are many similarities for The New Order, there are some games that shouldn’t change gameplay mechanics and The Old Blood is one of those games. Game reviewers or critics gave The Old Blood some solid reviews (or “mixed” with many won’t recommend the “full price”). In my personal point of view, The Old Blood is absolutely worth $20 or your regional equivalent. MachineGames broke off the common trend of expensive DLCs (with little content) and gave a full fledge expansion that is reasonably priced and justified. I commend the developers for making the right choice. For those who have The New Order, but didn’t get The Old Blood, I strongly encourage you to get the game. For the gamers who have not experience Wolfenstein, get The Old Blood first for the story, then get The New Order. The Old Blood is my personal favorite for 2015 as one of the best expansion (or “DLC”) to the well-established, 2014 game – The New Order. On a good discount or full price, this standalone expansion is worth your money. Without a doubt.

Upon finding out about this game, I wanted it immediatley. I love history and couldn't resist seeing what Wolfenstein: TOB would be like - And upon playing it, I was left speechless and blown away, more satisfied with a game experience than I ever have been before.   -   STORYLINE  - 10/10  No words can describe how beautiful the storyline is. It is so hard not to get attached to the characters, as their struggles are so humanly raw and real that you can't help but care with every ounce of your being, if not some small albeit meaningful part of your heart.   I cried when Wesley died; I was really determined to save him. You have no idea.     **Wolfenstein: The Old Blood progresses in 'chapters' that are well paced and helps give the game an organized feel. At any time you can go back on previously finished chapters and replay it, allowing limitless time to search for collectibles or just enjoy it all over again.    GAMEPLAY  - 8/10  Gameplay is exciting and rarely ever begins to feel repetitive. You can approach a situation through stealth or run in unabashed. There is a decent selection of weapons at your disposal, all very useful and effective in combat.   Adjusting game difficulty is easy should newer gamers start to feel overwhelmed. Advanced players will be happy to find that the harder settings are actually hard and do provide a refreshing challenge.  --------------------------------- There are 6 levels of difficulty:   CAN I PLAY, DADDY?  =  Very easy.    DON'T HURT ME  =  More difficult than the last level, damage from enemies has a higher impact on health and armor, demanding that the player think more on their feet while still leaving a gap of leniency for those still under experienced with FPS.    BRING 'EM ON!  =  This is the default or Normal difficulty. A comfortable middle.    I AM DEATH INCARNATE!  =  A nice challenge for those who enjoy FPS. Leniency for errors is almost non-exsistant.     ÜBER  =  Very hard.    MEIN LEBEN  =  You have one life. Die once, the game is over. All of your weapons become your lifeline, you rely totally on your skill to make it through.  ---------------------------------    SOUNDTRACK  - 10/10  The soundtracks send shivers down my spine and helps with immersion in a unique way. Somber, quick, or intense notes help to seal in the atmosphere of loss and bloody, sweaty determination of one man against impossible odds.      OVERALL - I highly recommend Wolfenstein: The Old Blood. It hasn't dissapointed me in any way, and while that may only be true for me personally, there's no denying this is an amazing game.

Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is one hell of an interesting expansion to its core game, The New Order. For those of you wondering, despite being a standalone game, The Old Blood does lead directly into The New Order, and given the oppurtunity I would absolutely recommend playing through The Old Blood first.  The Old Blood is an 8 chapter expansion that is suprisingly lengthy. My first playthrough took around 8 hours total to beat, though my second run took about half that time. During development, MachineGames took two individual ideas they had for expansion content, and combined them into one, giving us the two parts of The Old Blood: 'Rudi Jager and The Den of Wolves' and 'The Dark Secrets of Helga Von Schabbs'. The first part is by far the more standard of the two, whilst the second part veers into the occult elements that were amiss in The New Order for the most part.  Gameplay-wise, you're getting pretty much the exact same core mechanics, expect with a technical downgrade. As the game takes place 10 years prior to The New Order, BJ Blazkowicz has a significantly more aged arsenal to utilize. Thankfully, it's pretty much just as effective, and features some interesting additions such as a bolt-action sniper rifle, a grenade pistol, and optional dual-wielded pipes. Combat is arguably tougher then The New Order, as BJ is more restricted in how effectively he can tackle opponents, though it's still as fluid and enjoyable as it was in The New Order.  The Old Blood suffers most in the story and visual design elements. Don't get me wrong, the game looks fantastic and provides a number of beautiful vistas that double as challenging levels, however the level of environmental storytelling has decreased significantly. As has the effectiveness of the story. If The New Order told a fantastic story, The Old Blood tells one with similiar ambitions, but it's restricted in its length. Characters here still possess a similiar amount of notable traits and witty and passionate dialogue, the problem is there really isn't enough in it to truly engage the player. I only found the game getting particularly heavy at the very end, during the transition into The New Order.   Despite it's somewhat crammed and less effective story however, I still recommend it as a precursor to The New Order. The combat and overall flow of the game is excellent, and very reasonably priced for several hours worth of content. If you enjoyed The New Order, you'll likely just as much enjoy what's on offer here.

I'm still struggling to understand why more games can't play like Wolfenstein. The gameplay is incredibly addictive and fluent and nothing ever feels buggy. First of all, I would like to say that The New Order and The Old Blood has easily made their way into my top 10 games. This is what I would call SOLID games.   Here's what The Old Blood has to offer: - Unlockable Perks - Challenge Mode - Collectibles - A few new guns - New characters - Old characters - Nightmare levels - Backstory  The two games play exactly the same, with one or two elements changed or added. Playing The Old Blood made me long for The New Order. This is because the game lacks story depth and character developement, but I suppose it's only fair since it's a DLC. This is actually a good prequel to the new order. You once again play as Blazcowicz as you try to infiltrate the infamous 'Castle Wolfenstein' in search of intel on the nazi war machine. I think that its a little better than the new order, because its very fast paced. The thing I did not like is the fact they abuse stealth sequences, I mean you can either take that aproach or go completely 'Rambo-mode',but the fact is that they sometimes force you to be stealth or you have to restart the level and it gets plain annoying (unless playing on mein leben difficulty). The fact is that some enemies are not meant for stealth sequences. Like the shotgunner for example. Shotgun soldiers are a great idea in FPS games so it makes you feel that your not the only one using a shotgun. I see it in HL2 with combine shotgun soldiers for example, but this is where they screw it up: THEY GIVE THEM TO MUCH HP!!! IT MAKES THEM A PAIN TO DEAL WITH, plus you can't do a take down on them which really sucks, plus in my eyes the shotgun soldiers look more like the pyro from tf2 then shotgun soldiers. Here is something with the AI that sucks too (Well of course Bethesda made this so the AI is going to suck), When you are sneaking around and you are right in an enemy's field of vision they just sit there and act like you do not exist. HOW UNREALISTIC IS THAT... Word of advice to Bethesda: Improve your AI. Surprisingly though, because its a bethesda game I expected it to be like Fallout 4 and have tons of bugs and glitches, but instead the only bug I came across was a 'Panzerhund' not attacking me and standing still. Otherwise it was a smooth playthrough and I expirienced no bugs or glitches. Good work on that devs. Combat like the new order is still very, very smooth which makes it easy. I like FPS games with smooth gunplay, plus just like new order the muzzle effects and recoil of your gun seems so real. Its feels as if you are actually shooting it. Which I enjoy the realism. The game also included a bunch of minigames which made you find other routes to the end of the level in a set amount of time which gives the player a challenge to have them beat other players in these minigames, and I like that idea. There are and abundance of easter eggs too, like a skyrim helmet, doom plush toy, and much, much more! The weapons are nice as well. The minute I kill one of those murder bots. I pick up his weapon and I'm like: 'MG-42 MINIGUN!!! SWEET!!!' the assault rifle is a pimped out STG44, and  there is a jacked up Kar98k. The weapons were awesome and made me guess what real life ww2 weapons they could have originated from. One of the weapons I really like is the lead pipe, because not only can you smack people over the head with it (obviously) If there is a damaged wall you can use the pipes to climb it! I loved this aspect and thought it was pretty cool. Over all the rating I give Wolfenstein: The Old Blood on a 1 to 5 scale, a 4/5, because while it has sweet mechanics to it. It still needs work in areas like AI improvement, nerfing of certain enemies, bug fixing of that Panzerhund fight at the checkpoint to Castle Wolfenstein, and less stealth sequences. Thats my opinion of Wolfenstein: The Old Blood. I hope Machine Games and Bethesda continue to make expansions to there single player games as it tells a bit more of a story to the base game...

Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is difficult for me to actually recommend due to its very (in my opinion) cash-in feel; unlike its predecessor, The New Order, the game felt like boring to play at times and it was criminally short and easy. Whereas The New Order succeeded in blending together narrative, pacing, and gameplay into a single, satisfying package, The Old Blood's storyline and characters are exceedingly weak in comparison. After completing the game on its hardest difficulty in exactly five hours, I felt like the game could have been so much more than the end result ended up delivering.  While the overall game itself does not shine, the gameplay is still incredibly solid and slightly improves upon the systems in The New Order by making stealth a more viable option and giving the protagonist a melee weapon, allowing for more frantic close-quarters combat. The guns themselves all feel weighty and powerful, both in sound design and actual damage. Just like The New Order, The Old Blood allows for the player to dual-wield weapons and sprint around rapidly rather than succumbing to typical FPS tropes that force the player to take potshots from cover until all of the enemies in the next room are dead--this helps the game remain enjoyable to play throughout its duration. Unfortunately, while the combat is a blast, the difficulty is an absolute joke. The New Order certainly was not a hard game on Uber (the max, save for a few challenge modes) difficulty, but there was a spot or two that defintely caused me trouble. This wasn't the case with The Old Blood for me; I was a bit confused during the final boss fight, but after initally dying to it, the game essentially flat-out tells you how to beat it with a loading screen tip. This was the sole part of the game I found difficult to any degree, and while I suppose that it's better for a game to be moderately easy than for it to have enemies with massive health pools and one-shot attacks, I was expecting far more of a challenge than I actually received. The gunplay in the two modern Wolfenstein games is absolutely great, but I hope that for any future iterations, MachineGames strives to build a more difficult experience that truly tests the skill of its players.  As previously mentioned, the story, pacing, characters, et al. take a backseat to the gameplay in The Old Blood, which is fairly disappointing as the writing in The New Order was much better than I expected it to be. The game starts with the main character, BJ Blazkowicz, attempting to infiltrate the Nazi stronghold of Castle Wolfenstien in the midst of an alternate-history World War II in which the Allies are losing. His objective is to attempt to discover the location of Deathshead, who is later the main antagonist in The New Order. Of course, given that an FPS game wouldn't be much of an FPS game without combat, the infiltration fails spectacularly and Blazkowicz must attempt to escape from the facility and continue on with his mission in a much more violent manner than intended.   Despite the game's short runtime, it ends up being divided into two distinctive parts, with a major antagonist driving the conflict in each. The first half deals with a (fairly contrived) antagonist named Rudi Jäger, a tall and muscular German commander with a fetish for dogs and robotics. The only purpose that he serves is to spring up as a boss battle so that the two parts of the game can be somewhat thematically divided; he doesn't honestly show up that much prior to the fight and his character is poorly-developed at best. After his death, the main antagonist transitions to Helga von Schabbs, a very unhappy archaeologist who believes that she has the means to bring the war to an even quicker end with a discovery that she unearths. While Helga is a slightly better villan than Rudi is, mainly due to the fact that you can find some of her backstory littered about in the various notes in the game, she still pales in comparison to any of the villans in The New Order, especially Frau Engel, whose personality was all over the place (in a good way). It can be inferred that the reason for the lack of character and narrative development is that The Old Blood is a 'budget' title, leaving the short storyline at fault. Even though Helga is the main antagonist of the second half of the game (and, technically speaking, the game as a whole), you still don't get to see her very much; rather, a good portion of the second part is spent killing    zombies.    All in all, it would have been nice to see more character development for all of the characters, considering that it was one of the defining features of The New Order.  Again, this isn't to imply that The Old Blood is a bad game; it's still one of the best singleplayer FPS games in recent memory, and it manages to stand out above the rest with its fast-paced and enjoyable combat. However, The New Order, was a far, far superior game in every single aspect except for gameplay. The price difference between the two reflects this, but regardless, wait for a sale and don't come into The Old Blood expecting a 'worthy' successor to The New Order. Given that The New Order ended on a cliffhanger, one can only hope that The Old Blood is serving to deliver a bit more Wolfenstein while MachineGames develops a true sequel.

3 / 5  Might as well be called 'Return to Wolfenstein', but still worth the price of admission (once you wait for it to go on sale).  B.J. is back in the expansion to The New Order...putting the Wolfenstein hero back in the WWII era killing Nazi's of every size and type. Storyline is utterly forgettable with characters that are interesting enough, but don't approach the level of those found in The New Order. Still, they are adequate and used to foreshadow / provide some interesting insights into where some of the things from The New Order came from. Of note, there's an element of humor in B.J.'s musings this time around and I think there was a concerted effort to show the character of B.J. showing the strain of his previous adventures and the slow descent into the quasi craziness exhibited in The New Order. In general, it works and was a welcoming 'lightening' of the game that provides a direct prelude to the events of The New Order.  The majority of the game follows the same action/stealth combination so successful in the main game, but tends to do a better job of implementing them into realistic gameplay. Too often, The New Order forced you out of stealth into a needless gunbattle. The Old Blood lets stealth portions be stealth, combat sections be combat, and generally leaves open areas enough methods to deal with enemies as the player sees fit. There's a few places where things seem forced on the player, but they are few and far between. Weapons / enemies are almost exactly the same and those that are different are slight variations on what already exists. As such, you'll spend most of the time with the same 'favorite' you always used.   The main gripe in this game comes in the last chapters, encompassing roughly 2 hours of gameplay. Basically once zombies show up the game gets very repetitive and downright boring. Zombies do a lot of damage in melee (at least on Uber) but are slow, shambling creatures that somehow manage to get an insane burst of speed when they get close. This would normally create some tense situations in most games, but level design bounces between 'too large and thus far too easy to kill zombies before they become a threat' and 'so claustrophobic it feels cheap when I get hit by a zombie from behind'. In addition, zombies seem to always know where you are making stealth in their areas at least extremely difficult if not outright impossible. As if that wasn't enough, some zombies still carry their guns and will fire at you with surprising accuracy. For some reason that just simply doesn't feel right...The final negative is the final boss battle. Using a strange combination of stealth centric combat you alternate between shooting an ancient monster in the mouth, moving silently around the space, and getting the boss to kill waves of Nazi's for you (since the monster cannot see, only attacks by sound). To point, even on Uber it is extremely repetitive, easy, and downright not fun.  In any case, the majority of this game was fun and provides much of the same gameplay of what The New Order provides, albeit with less of the style the previous game had, but has too dissappointing an ending. Still, worth the price of a Steam sale and a definate recommend to any FPS fan.

Excellent First person shooter. Excellent graphics and graphic details.   But there was something missing from the story both going through the village and dealing with the SS Paranormal division.   There were fewer overheard conversations (stories) in the village, too many locked building doors, and SS Paranormal was simply zombies dropping from the sky and a big monster at the end.   SS Paranormal in 'Return to Castle Wolf' were beautiful women with machine guns (in a church, in a mansion, and finally in the graveyard). The variety of settings and difference in gameplay were good aspects. Also, you would overhear more conversations with the 'Return to Castle Wolf' SS Paranormal than you do with this game (Wolf the old blood).   I enjoyed dealing with the talking monster king at the end of 'Return to Castle Wolf' more than the monster at the end of this game. He had more personality; wanted to take over the world; and turned Helga into his zombie slave in 'Return to Castle Wolf' ... that was much better than the non-speaking monster at the end of this game who's most endearing aspect was his ability to deal blunt force trauma.   'Return to Castle Wolf' also allowed you to sneak around the village more. This game (Wolf the old blood) on the other hand was a constant fire fight. Suppose I could try harder at stealth but .... this doesn't seem like a stealth game. You run into one tough opponent and the stealth game is over.   This game is also more dark and serious than 'Return to Castle wolf.' Not as much humor, and our hero, William J. Blazkowicz, does not vacation on the front lines of the war killing Nazi for fun.
